title: Citi Officially Opens in China (Shanghai) Pilot Free Trade Zone
summary: Shanghai - Citibank (China) Co., Ltd. ("Citi China") today announced the official opening of its new sub-branch in China (Shanghai) Pilot Free Trade Zone ("FTZ"), Citibank (China) Co., Ltd. Shanghai Free Trade Zone sub-branch ("Citi China FTZ Sub-branch").
tag-1: Citi Officially Opens in China (Shanghai) Pilot Free Trade Zone
tag-3: Shanghai – Citibank (China) Co., Ltd. ("Citi China") today announced the official opening of its new sub-branch in China (Shanghai) Pilot Free Trade Zone ("FTZ"), Citibank (China) Co., Ltd. Shanghai Free Trade Zone sub-branch ("Citi China FTZ Sub-branch").
tag-4: Part of Citi China's Shanghai branch, the FTZ sub-branch will provide a full range of foreign currency and RMB services under the regulatory framework to customers. With an initial focus on corporations in the zone with cross-border financial needs, the sub-branch will strive to provide a range of comprehensive banking products and services, including global cash management, cross-border trade finance and financial market products.
tag-5: Andrew Au, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Citi China, said, "We are excited to embark on this new chapter in our franchise growth in China. We look forward to capitalizing on the opportunities brought by the financial reform in the zone, as well as connecting Citi's global network and expertise with local talent and insights to create a win-win-win situation for our customers, our business and the country's economy."
tag-6: As a leading financial services institution, Citi China has always been at the forefront of the financial reforms in China. Since the establishment of the FTZ, Citi China has held a number of seminars within and outside of China for corporate clients and partners to introduce and interpret relevant policies in the zone. These have all received positive feedback.
tag-7: Prior to today's opening, Citi piloted a series of market-firsts treasury solutions for clients that leverage the latest financial policies in the FTZ. Examples include launching the RMB cross-border automatic sweeping, automated two-way RMB cross-border pooling, and RMB cross-border POBO ROBO and netting solutions. In future, with the gradual implementation of policies in the FTZ, Citi China will further expand its business scope and scale in this sub-branch under the framework of regulatory guidelines.
tag-8: The new sub-branch is located at No. 2001 North Yanggao Road in Shanghai. Business departments include Citi Commercial Bank, Treasury and Trade Solutions and the Markets.
tag-9: Citi Citi, the leading global bank, has approximately 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 160 countries and jurisdictions. Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.
tag-10: Additional information may be found at www.citigroup.com | Twitter: @Citi | YouTube: www.youtube.com/citi | Blog: http://blog.citigroup.com | Facebook: www.facebook.com/citi | LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/citi
tag-11: Citi China  Citi first established an office in China on May 15, 1902, in Shanghai. In April 2007, Citi was among the first international banks to locally incorporate in China. Citi's locally incorporated entity is known as Citibank (China) Co Ltd, which is wholly owned by Citibank N.A. Today Citi is a leading international bank in China, and has 55 branches and sub-branches in thirteen cities across China (Beijing, Changsha, Chengdu, Chongqing, Dalian, Guangzhou, Guiyang, Hangzhou, Nanjing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, Tianjin, Wuxi). With operations in more than 160 countries around the world, Citi is the most global of all international banks in China.
